In 2017 I was itching for a Metro/Stalker experience in VR. Seeing this was being made by the creators of Metro with the "world building and immersion 4A is known for" I had high hopes. 
It ended up being a Time Crisis game in a creepy-ish setting. Not anything close to what I hoped.

If you're looking for VR Metro, this game isn't even close. Play Radius.
If you are a Time Crisis fan and want to support 4A, you'll enjoy this. 

I do hope 4A and Dimitri decide to create a proper VR Metro installment that plays like Into The Radius. Something with a top notch story and atmosphere we're used to. I want to experience Metro with my bare hands, outside of Airsoft apocalypse RP events.

review_title: Early pre-pre-pre alpha of a cool game.
one_reviews_text:
Arktika.1 is based on an interesting idea for a VR FPS. It has no form of artificial locomotion so you're forced to physically dodge in and out of cover. This makes for intense viscerally exciting gunfights, and makes the game feel like an extended lightgun shooter ala Time Crisis. 

Unfortunately it's just not even close to being finished. They got as far as getting a theoretical game beginning to end and then just dumped it on the store. The enemies do almost no damage and the AI simply cannot handle you using the teleport system to jump from one cover point to another. You can get an absolutely basic challenge out of it if you set the difficulty to hard (once you even find it, the difficulty settings are buried deep) and then never once upgrade your guns. 

Worse still there's no way to center your playspace. The devs forcibly disabled the Oculus menu so there's absolutely no way to change it. If your playspace is 10x10m or above you're probably fine but if not it will probably just dump critical items outside of your defined play area making progression literally impossible.

It had potential, but the game isn't ready for testing, let alone release.

Arktika.1 is a bit of an unfortunate game. The graphics are good, although the scale of the hands and weapons seem a bit off. The setting has potential, although it isn't really explored to the full extent that it could be. There is the seed of a good game here.

Unfortunately, whatever potential the game had is ruined by two serious mistakes. First of all, the node teleport system in this game is absolutely horrid. It doesn't feel like you are moving through the level, as much as jumping disjointedly around it.

You jump too far with each teleport and often change the direction you're facing (thanks original Rift front facing setup!). This makes it very difficult to even keep your sense of orientation. To me it felt like I was jumping around from one scene to the next, with no real sense of tbe environment I was moving through, or how it was put together.

Combat is ruined by the node teleport, too. You just hop around from one place to another, while the enemies run around in circles trying to keep up with you. On the one hand it feels overpowered, on the other hand totally lame. Sorry, but this teleport method was just a bad idea all around.

The second problem is the weapon balance is terrible. Some weapons, like the laser, are laughably overpowered. Just upgrade the laser and the whole game becomes a total joke, even on hard. Other weapons, like the plasma bolt gun and the "shotgun", are totally worthless. They are simply weak and ineffective to use-worse than the starting gun.

Also, it seems the mercenary you play is either too poor, or too stupid to carry a flashlight on his belt. Totally contrived.

Overall, the best thing that can be said about Arktika.1 is that someone had to make this mistake, so no one else would. It's just too bad, because the game had a seed of potential, it just needed more polish and a less stupid locomotion mechanic.

As it stands, there are much better VR games available now. Save yourself the grief and just skip this early title.

Arktika is a blast, especially if you have a beefy system that can supersample at 1.6+. 

Teleportation: I am sympathetic with those that dislike it. In Robo Recall teleportation can be justified because you are basically a superman, a "recaller". We can imagine the recaller to have certain teleportative abilities as part of his job and skill set. In Arktika this isn't the case. The teleportation is a crutch. It takes away from truly appreciating the beautiful sets 4AGames has created. You are zooming through shining, devastated vistas much too fast. TP also makes the game easier than it should be, even on hard settings. That said, you get past the small disappointment with teleportation after your first mission. You just don't care about it anymore. The game is too fun to let this mechanic ruin it. 

Scaling: People complaining about scaling must have man-baby hands. You are in the arctic cold. You would have to wear huge gloves (hockey gloves?) to resist that cold. I like the fact that your hands actually look and feel like real-sized human hands in weather proof gloves. Your enemies are big; decked out in heavy, cold-insulated armor. The games developers are Ukrainian! Have you seen some of those dudes? They're big dudes! :) Victoria is a life sized android. She's hot. I have a bit of a crush on her. Why? Because she's a six foot goddess. I'll take that kind of scaling. 

Gameplay: Fast, fun, creepy, furious at times. Still a bit too easy. Needs a few more enemies in the big set pieces. Gun choice is great, but the upgrades are a bit too powerful. If you don't spend any money after your first mission, you can buy the Ikari and upgrade it completely before the beginning of the THIRD mission and have the most powerful tool in the game. 
Tip: For an amazing experience, open your  real windows/let the cold in. Blast a house fan at you. Get COLD. Get air moving around. Wear light clothes. SHIVER! Best sense experience ever. Also, "yell". And see your breath in game.

Finished playing through the entire game, and of all the VR games I've played (which is nearly all of them), this one is probably the hardest to review because of the gigantic, almost impossibly huge gap between the pros and the cons.  Going from bad to great:

-Extremely easy, even on the hard setting.  If you use the laser-style gun + enemy outline attachment and shield which are all easy to get, the game offers absolutely 0 challenge.
-Extremely limited enemy variety.  3 "bosses" none of which are particularly good or interesting fights.
-The gameplay/missions as a whole are easy, simplistic, just generally boring.  No replayability, no challenge.
-The movement system is horrible.  No free movement, and not even free teleport.  You can only move to predefined positions, and only at predefined times.  The worst part is you can't fully appreciate the environments (see below for why this is a CRIME AGAINST GAMERS)
+/- The narrative/story is decent if predictable and cliche, definately not great, but not terrible.
+/- The weapon variety is quite good and diverse, but one gun/mod is so much better that all the rest are completely pointless unless you are trying to artificially challenge yourself.
+++ The graphics and set/environment designs.  Oh. My. God.  You have never seen anything like this in any VR game.  Stuff like Lone Echo might be a high school intro to MS Paint project compared to this.  This would be a 1-star game for sure, but just because of the graphics this gets a recommend from me.  The jaw-dropping beauty of this art and attention to detail makes the huge shortcomings of the rest of this game even worse, because if the entire game was up to the quality set by the art and environment design, this would be Game of the Decade, no contest.  I truly hope some better studio, working on a better game, plays Arktika.1 and sees the talent of the people who made the graphics so they can hire them.

This game has beautiful graphics, and the gunplay is pretty good as well.  This game also has some pretty innovative ideas and setpieces, and it works especially well in a room-scale environment.  This is a node-based game as others have described it, which works because the cover and gunplay are done well.  The problem with this game is that it is very buggy.  Guns can disappear during gameplay without returning unless you start over, and nodes sometimes just disappear, including nodes that are required for the story to continue.  On top of this, I experienced a hard crash at the end of the last level, which meant that I had to play that level over.  Fortunately the last level is pretty fun, but it was still pretty annoying.  I'm genuinely pretty surprised at how many bugs I encountered over the course of playing the game.  I've had to start many missions over because of these bugs.  Some more QA would have gone a long way with this title, as the bugs do impare one's ability to continue through the game.  Buyer beware.

review_title: Basically Dead and Buried meets COD
one_reviews_text: I've only played an hour but, I have a few things to say thus far.   Ok imagine playing dead and burried where your cover is constantly breaking down. THrow in some intense scenes where monsters are comming at you from ALL angles in dark places.  Then through in the Reward/Upgrade Scheme.  The acting is pretty Cliche'.. but the environments.. boy the guys put some work on this.  THere are some scenes that simply look real.. like you feel like you really are there.  More a since of Awe , unless its the Cannabals comming to eat you.   The interaction with the envrionment is really lacking.. even though they put a lot work on getting certain physics down (like touching a bottle on the desk and it tipping over based on your force of touch).  Another thing.. the people are HUGE.. your hands are HUGE.. the lady talking to you  is an AMAZON..  All in the all the game is a 4 stars.  THe reason its not Five is because of the node based travel.  THe world is cool and atmosphere is interesting.. why stop us from just checking it out?  You could allow free rain  even if it just some limited teleportation spots like in Arizona Sunshine.  Then add in some secret power ups.. like in Dead Space.  Make us upgrade based on what we find.. not on Rewards.  (THats just a thought).  Lastly.. Add in some Melee and  you have a 5 star triple A gold mine.  Oh yeah .. Ditch the attractive chick to guide you along..I don't think sex appeal lures you in as much as Personality.  This game has Dead Space in VR in gleaming lights.  One awesome perk is using the cover.. would have been better if you could teleport like in Robo Recall where it slows down.. but then when you teleport , you can highlight the places where you can post for cover.  But somehow fit in some free rain.

review_title: Most fun game I played in VR in 2017
one_reviews_text: I wrote a lengthy review of this game when released, which had about 18 likes. Then I upgraded to the Oculus Core 2.0 beta and it disappeared! Can't be arsed to write another big roundup especially as there are thousands of reviews now and it's not needed, but had to show my support for this game. It feckin rocks! Teleportation system actually works really well, always transporting you to the optimum location. Some might prefer joystick locomation but the payoff is much richer environments to interact with. Instead of sliding around sterile corridors, strafing left and right to avoid bullets like in Raw Data for example, this game has you diving underneath cars, crouching behind walls, hiding in skips with retractable sides you can raise and lower for cover. In other words, it feels more virtually real, which is what you want in virtual reality. Combat usually involves being teleported into a scene where you are attacked by a succession of enemies. You need to quickly work out where the threats are coming from and what your best source of cover is. Playing on hard I was literally curled up on my floor at times, pinned down by enemy fire behind a tiny metal railing, and then popping up to rain death on them as they were trying to reload. Needs to be played on hardest setting to appreciate fully, with at least three sensors and rift headset cable extensions so that you have true roomscale and can reallly move around and interact with the excellent environment. 10/10 game for me.

review_title: Good but the mechanics kill it for me
one_reviews_text:
So, I typically don't write reviews. I personally feel that one individuals opinion cannot necessarily encapsulate anothers. However, in this case, I do want to tell others what this game is/isn't.

First, graphics and audio are first-rate, AAA VR quality. Visually, it's great, perhaps being one of the best visual VR games.
However, as others have mentioned, it's annoying to just teleport to a predetermined area. I get it. That's the design and works well for most firefights. However, the designer in this case remove the freedom of being in VR by doing so. If you've played Wilson's Heart, you'll know what I'm referring to. Personally, I believe that the devs should allow the users to select the choice of movement. This principle alone removes a star in rating.
The other aspect that is a negative is that you can't save anywhere. You need to complete an entire section before the auto-save occurs. Someimes that can be at great length. To restart back at the begining because I had another immediate obligation outside of the game is poor. It's a simple shooter at heart, every level. Why would you need to keep replaying levels? Maybe to extended the game length? I'm unsure of the logic here.
So, it is a good game, it has a good story, but you really need to be aware of two things prior to going in, as stated above. If you're good with that, then it's a good VR shooter.

At last...another game worthy of Lone Echo. Although I've only played the first mission I am having a blast, excuse the pun. The teleportation system works like a charm and I don't think I would have it any other way to be honest. I think it would trigger, no pun intended again, my motion sickness if it were free movement as the action is quite frantic.

I have had no scaling problems. The only problem I have had is my play space isn't that big so have had to recentre myself on occasion to reach items...but it's no deal breaker.

Everything about this game is top notch...so far. Runs smooth as silk too.

I have rated the game purely on its merits and not on my room space or potato others seem to be playing this title on. Don't rate the game down when the problems are of your own making!

Well done 4A Games!

The difficulty could be harder, although I did die a handful of times. The game was also quite buggy, I especially found it difficult to unholster my guns at times. A patch last week seems to have fixed some of these bugs, but for me specifically it seems to have introduced one where after about 20 minutes I got random blackouts of the display for a second or two. I can't be certain whether it's due to the game or new nvidia drivers which came around the same time, however it only seems to happen on this game. But I managed to finish the game anyway. I don't see myself going back to replay it because it really was quite repetitive, and also I think most of the guns and attachments were kinda meh, and I ended up using the default two pistols with only the laser and torch attachments throughout the whole game. Good game but nowhere near as good as Robo Recall. But worth playing still as it has quite different gameplay.

Other reviews are right; movements are extremely limited, and you can only jump through predetermined positions. However, this allows for no-fiddling, rapid combats and that's an interesting way to deal with fluidity. The story, the graphics, the environments are absolutely amazing. For me, that's a must play. I was really excited to play this game and after finishing it... well let's just say this game is not bad but has some problems.

Things I liked:
 - Guns. Guns in this game are fun to use, they look good (futuristic look) and are in sufficient variety. Many have secondary fire mode that's activated by holding the fire button. There are also a lot of mods for your weapons.
- Environment. Aesthetics and atmosphere are all great. You are mostly in frozen ruins with pretty good lighting. Everything just feels so... right. The ambient sounds and stuff is also solid.

Things I did not like:
- Gameplay. Ok let's start with the meat of the game and that is gameplay. Gameplay felt ok. That's it. Not bad, not horrible, not good or not great. Just ok. Main reason for this is very static combat and that's because you can only teleport to certain locations. You can duck or lean to avoid fire or teleport to other location but it all feels so restrictive. You cannot progress until you kill everything. Combat is for the most part just shooting galeries that you teleport to (except few bossfight). Only thing that save the gameplay are fun to use guns.
- No exploration. You cannot actively explore the level. You are very restricted where you can teleport to. And since levels are so very nice looking and there is all this clutter everywhere it just begs to be explored. That is not allowed for the most part.
- Enemy variety. It's bad. Three types of dudes with guns, one drone type (I think) and one monster type. There are also bosses but also only a few.
- Bug. I played it on launch and there were a couple of bugs that made me restart the level that I was 20 min in. 2 times. Also other mini bugs here and there. Probably patched already but still worth a mention.

FUN... when it works. It's a visually appealing game with a lot of shooting and action. The game uses a limited teleportation system with specific positions which limits the game in some ways but still gives you an authentic VR experience. Thankfully, the teleport system places you behind over where it's bloody fun to peek around one side of the barrier and take out a few baddies then pop out on the other side to finish up. You also earn different powers such as slow time and bubble shield like Halo to enhances your feeling of badassness. In spite of the fun, there are critical bugs that prohibit progression of the game while on a mission but it's been happening less and less. One example, I switched out the fuses for a door, which I have done before and know how to do, and nothing would happen. I would be stuck and have to start all over. This is very frustrating when you invest 30 minutes in to the game. Why not implement a checkpoint system within a mission to revert back to? If there is one I didn't see it. Also, I feel like there were a lot of wasted opportunities and space where there could have been more action or jump scares. In conclusion, it's a good experience. And your partner is hot.

review_title: Already one of my favorite Shooters
one_reviews_text:
Great, polished shooter. Didn't encounter any bugs or crashes until now (level6). Graphics, Sounds, Game mechanics are all done very well.

About teleportation: i dont understand the hate people express towards mechanics like these. I dont get motion sick and enjoy locomotion games like the Serious Sam Remakes, Compound (check this marvel out, its even free!!), Onward and the like.

But true VR should not rely on locomotion, it reduces the games to a standart FPS with a fancy display. In Artica, you dont have to worry about your playspace and real world position. Overall, I enjoyed the gameplay. Some things, though, were not smoothed out.
1. Game crashes: I only came across these two or three times, but it always happened at nearly the end of a level. The game has plenty of checkpoints throughout a level, so if you die you don't go too far back. If the game completely closes, though, you have to start the level completely over; therefore, if the game crashes, you lose all progress on a level, even though it had been saving.
2. Character speech: The antagonists often continued to speak even after being killed.
3. A little over-scaled: This didn't bother me too much, but it was enough to be noticed.
4. Buggy teleportation: Moving in this game is pre-set. Too often, it would end up either teleporting me to somewhere I didn't intend to go or just not teleport me at all.

So in summary, it's fun, but needs some work to get it fully fixed up.

I'm going to assume that you are already probably aware that the locomotion in this game is teleport only (although you are free to move around within the confines of your room space from any given teleport location of course), and either you are okay with that or you aren't.

Personally I did't mind the teleport mechanic - when you get into the flow it feels fairly natural and easy to use and it's still a dynamic game with crouching behind cover, leaning out etc... The game is completely built around this mechanic so I certainly wouldn't hope for any mods in future to change it to free locomotion, you just need to accept it for what it is.

So, what is it - in a word, pretty fun. Certainly one of the better VR experiences I've had outside of driving/flying games... it's fairly easy and you don't often feel like you are in mortal danger, though it is worth noting that  the game defaults to easy (and a lower gfx setting for that matter) so consider changing that around. Moments involving the yagas can be genuiniely creepy and sometimes it's a relief to get back to shooting the significantly less threatening human opponents.

The guns are mostly fun and are satisfyingly visceral... I love the setup for adding/removing attachments. I do wish that you could buy more than one of the same gun to allow you to dual wield with the same weapon. Different reload mechanics in each hand can sometimes get a bit tedious...

Definitely worth a punt at what I think is a fair enough price for a good 4-5 hours of entertainment from a single play through. It's a good solid piece of light entertainment that won't challenge your brain too much with the simple puzzles and can be played in relatively short bite sized chunks as time allows - it would be nice however if they allowed a save game option so you could pick up where you left off on a given mission if you need to stop playing.

I think I'm only 3 or 4 missions into the game currently and I've been quite enjoying it. But already I've run into some pretty significant bugs. I've had the game completely crash twice, resetting any progress in that mission (the first time was right at the end of the first 'boss', so that was a pain). In my most recent play session, the gesture sensing wasn't working properly which made interacting with the various buttons and controls around the place more difficult(it was definitely the game because the Oculus settings menu thing was still registering it perfectly).

If you're willing to look past the bugs, it's a fairly standard cover shooter but designed from the ground up for VR (quite successfully in my opinion). The production quality is relatively high. I have almost no clue what the plot is - I clearly haven't found it engaging but ymmv.

I really expected to love this game, but from the get go I was disappointed.

Graphics: The use of subsampling at Medium and especially High settings is unacceptable, it completely breaks any possible immersion (and enjoyment, personally) because of the blurriness. I would prefer 100% render resolution with less graphical details; I hope you eventually provide better graphics options. Apart from the graphics, the scaling of everything feels wrong.

Interface: I found the right hand menu awkward to use as a right hander. It would have be better if we had the option to choose the dominant hand which changes the placement of the menu. Also, why are the weapons only on the shoulders? I personally find it clunky and it confounds me why the standard waist holsters aren't used.

Give us more options.

EDIT: Forgot to add, why do we have to hold the grip button to hold a weapon? I'm already holding the controller which is enough. The grip button should be a toggle.

one_reviews_text: Single arcade shooter at its best: stunning visuals, atmosphere, and environments (extreme setting); fast paced gameplay; straight forward story and puzzle progression; authentic feel of weaponry, upgrades, and attachments; solid acting and character presentation.  The game felt right, it felt natural to hold and use weapons. Likewise, interaction with the environment came as a second nature with enough room scale accessibility, of course.  Great use of a cover system and cover switching via node placement around the perimeter.  Don't know why people complain about scaling issues, when in comparison, everything else is bigger than normal.  Now, to the cons and why I took away a star.  This would not come as a surprise, but I would have liked an option for free locomotion.  I know the game wasn't designed for it from ground up and I understand why, but leaving such beautiful environments mostly untouched is little disappointing.  Second, there are few glitches when it came to puzzle solving and progression.  For example, during the Cargo stage mission, I had to move a container inside the unit B3 I believe.  While doing so, I had to use a crane to place it on the right train car in order to move it forward.  So I placed a container a little too close to me instead of placing it on the end of a train car.  I thought that I can just use the crane to adjust the placement but no luck, crane would not latch to the container no matter how many times and positions I tried.  So I had to finally restart the level in order to move forward.  I'm sure these bugs could be worked out in the near future and developer probably looking into it as we speak.  In conclusion, this is a definite buy for any VR shooter junkie out there. Arktika.1 is a title that makes you invest in VR gaming.  This game should set a standard for production value so I don't have to expect anything less from other experienced developers moving forward.

One of a few true AAA for VR by the end of 2017.
Speaking formal - it is "just another VR shooting gallery". Yet it made carefully and well polished in terms of gameplay, it does have plot and several hours of gameplay, it has additional progression by managing weapong and upgrades for them, so at the end it feels very solid and valuable.

Teleportation is implemented in a smart way - every point in meaningful and you can navigate very fast whiting combat. The downside - lack of any exploration, the game is completely linear.
Shooting is also implemented properly: bullets flies at finite speed - not slow, but just to make player notice trajectory and adjust aiming. There are a lot of targets to test the gun in an armory. Every successfull hit gives solid feedback. Reloading is fun and simple, the game not bother you with fiddling reloading and counting every bullet - you can't drop all magazines to the floor and get eaten by zombies :)

But there is some odd issues about performance. Maybe it is just because of my way to play the game, but on GTX1060 it runs not very smooth, there are short freezes and sudden frame drops. review_title: It's great, but it's not amazing.
one_reviews_text: Arktika.1 is fantastic at moments but it's dragged down by wonky physics, a strange over-all scale, and the same cheap tactic to lengthen game time by revisiting maps you've already visited ( like robo-recall). Now I can't comment on the performance, I am using Revive (I'll be honest) and I think it would be unfair to judge the optimization. I still recommend the game, it's a joy to play and smells of AAA quality, but it falls flat in some crucial areas.  It's however half the price of a full release AAA and VR, go for it. 4/5
